title: history-detectives-ask-where-did-the-picts-go
story: But now a long-running project to shine a light on the Dark Age Picts of north-east Scotland has found that, far from being backward natives on Europersquos fringes, they were a sophisticated people with a developed culture whose reach stretched to the eastern shores of the Mediterranean and beyond.For six years the Northern Picts Project, which is mostly run by the University of Aberdeen, has been probing the secrets of one of Caledoniarsquos earliest people to expand upon their place in Scotlandrsquos story.The Picts arose around the third century AD to dominate parts of north-east Scotland, Orkney and Shetland until they mysteriously disappeared around  AD, leaving behind only a written record of their kings, scattered archaeological remains and strange carved stones dotted around the land.Even the name they called themselves has been lost, as Roman writers dubbed them Picts because of their habit of painting, or likely tattooing, their bodies.The Scotland they knew was a dferent world compared to the modern one.Wolves and bears still roamed in wild lands and elk and boar could be hunted in the forests.People were chiefly organised into scattered farming and fishing communities, and society was only just leaving its tribal past behind.Over time, myths have grown up around the Picts, such as the claim of the ancient writer Bede, who insisted the Picts were descended from Scythian tribes who migrated from the shores of the Black Sea.Professor Gordon Noble, who heads up the Aberdeen University project, explained that the lack of written sources makes the period dficult to study.He said: ldquoYou can take what Bede says with a lot of salt. We do not have a huge amount of knowledge of the Picts in terms of historical sources and what we do have is mostly from external ones.ldquoTherersquos late Roman writings and Irish and Anglo-Saxon sources but all we have from the Picts themselves is the lsquoking listrsquo.ldquoThey are most likely a collection of the Iron Age tribes which lived in Scotland at the time slowly coming together to form a cohesive kingdom.The project set out to investigate sites close to long-standing symbol stones to carry out fresh excavations in the hope of forming a better understanding of this mysterious people.A major discovery was made at Rhynie in Aberdeenshire, a landlocked village south of Huntly on the A, where eight carved Pictish stones ndash among them the carved ldquoRhynie man and the Craw Stane ndash had long been known about.Archaeologists now believe the site was home to a major royal enclosure comprised of several buildings, one of them constructed from massive curved oak beams, surrounded by a wooden wall four to five metres high.But it was fragments from Roman vases known as amphorae recovered in digging work which provided the most tantalising clue to the reach of the Picts.Vase pieces have been found at only three other sites in Scotland, including Dumbarton Rock, the seat of the ancient rulers of the Kingdom of Strathclyde.Those found at Rhynie indicate it may well have been the dwelling place of a high-status Pictish ruler whose world stretched far beyond the north-east.The few records that remain also suggest the Picts may have had a far more unied kingdom than their neighbours to the west, organised along lines seen in Europe and to the south in England.Mr Noble said: ldquoRhynie is the most northern site these fragments have been found at, and they show that the Picts were part of a trading network which stretched far and wide into the Roman world.ldquoThe Picts are quite unusual in having an over-kingship of such an extensive area. In Ireland at this time therersquos more than  or so petty kings ruling very small kingdoms but what we see in Pictland is something thatrsquos a lot more like the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms.ldquoThese are not a people on the edge of Europe but one thatrsquos developing like its southern and eastern neighbours.ldquoThere are influences of western art and a great deal of commerce. The Picts are very much a part of wider European developments.More recently, the projectrsquos archaeologists probed the symbol stones themselves and concluded they contain writing as well as art. Crucially, they claim, this developed in the third century and was likely influenced through contact with the written word of the Romans.It is now believed the symbols carved into the stones were a form of naming system that communicated the identities of Pictish people and places and are the last surviving fragments of their language.Mr Noble said: ldquoThese stones occur at prominent places in the land and on Christian Cross slabs on graves, most likely telling something about the personrsquos rank and identity. They were probably developed in a similar way to Ogham script in Ireland and Scandinavian runes.While the Northern Picts Project has gone a long way to re-evaluating their place in Scottish history, much still needs to be done to flesh out the picture.Current work centres on a large fort at Burghead on the Moray coast. This site, which was destroyed in the ninth century, may hold clues to the eventual fate of the Picts.While there is evidence of a slow merging with the western kingdom of the Gaels, the people of the north-east were facing a new threat: the Vikings.Mr Noble added: ldquoThe Vikings were bad news for just about everybody in this period. But therersquos still much we need to know before we can say where the Picts went.

title: tv-review-is-the-new-bbc-scotland-channel-magic-or-mince
story: Three, two, one went the countdown and there was Chvrches singer Lauren Mayberry singing a number which would not be out of place in the next Bond film. Programming proper began, oddly, with A Night at the Theatrehosted by Iain Stirling, the voice of Love Island, the ITV reality show infamous for the thickness of the contestants and the thinness of the sheets under which they have sex on camera.ChVrches and SSO open new channelIf you know who Stirling is then you are probably the target demographic of the new channel. If not, then you, like me, are part of the fuddy duddy majority, those who sit down to an eveningrsquos viewing as we would a meal, consuming one programme after another till wersquove had enough, or the wine runs out. The Love Island lot are the take away set, snacking on ldquocontent" whenever and wherever they choose, either on social media or iPlayer.Whatever your age, the only thing worse than A Night at the Theatre would have been an afternoon in surgery. Tired, unfunny and peppered with audience participation games, it made The Good Old Days look like Sinatra at the Sands.        name : ballot,target: ballot_,params:.pushSTV, which closed down last year after failing to attract enough viewers, was run on pound million a year, bawbees in TV terms. BBC Scotland has pound million, but from that sum, which would buy three and a bit hours of Netflixrsquos The Crown, it has to fund  hours of programmes. Getting Hitched Asian Stylegave a hint of how the new channel would make the pennies stretch. A documentary about wedding planners Saffron Events, it had good talkersand some mild drama , but it was baggy and repetitive, just about it making it to an hourrsquos worth of material. There are two more parts to come. Is there really more to say YouTube star on new seriesThe Peoplersquos Newsgave people the chance to, er, give us their views on the news. There was one official taxi driver on it, and lots of people who could have been taxi drivers so in love were they with the sound of their own voices. A little bit Gogglebox, and accompanied by a head-splitting soundtrack, the hipsters at Channel  news will be kicking themselves they did not think of this first.At last, a proper event for event TV: the first episode of the final series of Still Game . With the dreadful timing of the Scotland football squad, the gang have found their form again when it no longer matters. The story about Jack and Victor entering the YouTube age was about as original as jokes about cat videos, but it left plenty of room for what SG does best: daftness laced with cyanide-strength sarcasm Burnistoun Tunes Inwas patchy, but some of the old stuff still works a treat. The nightrsquos final offering was the brilliant documentary Nae Pasaran , about a boycott by Scots engineers that curbed Pinochetrsquos bombing of his own people. Running it earlier would have given the channel a stamp of quality and seriousness, which it needed.Tutti Frutti is backLast night was supposed to be about the thrill of the new,there is such a thing any more in a multichannel world, yet there was something familiar about the evening. It took a while to pin down, then it came to me. The widely-trailedof favourite shows that inevitably struggled to live up to expectations, lots of familiar faces, a whf of prissiness. Yes, it was Hogmanay TV, but on a Sunday in February. BBC Scotland director Donalda MacKinnon has said the channelrsquos goal is "success over time". Consider the clock ticking.

title: prime-minister-aims-to-push-ahead-with-domestic-agenda-once-uk-has-left-eu
story: The Prime Minister insisted her job was not only about delivering Brexit on the scheduled date of March , but also dealing with issues like the NHS.Mrs May stressed that, once the UK had formally withdrawn from the EU, a new future partnership deal with the bloc needed to be hammered out.The PMs comments come after she made it clear to Tory MPs in December that she would not lead the party into the next scheduled General Election in .That move was thought to have helped Mrs May survive a vote of no confidence in her leadership before Christmas.Her remarks also follow reports that some ministers want her to quit after the May local elections.Referencing her pledge to create a fairer society when she first entered Downing Street, Mrs May said: "I was very clear in December with the Conservative Party that as far as Im concerned, what I am doing, my job is not only about delivering Brexit, actually theres a domestic agenda that I am delivering on."It reflects what I said on the doorstep of Number Ten when I first became Prime Minister."Thats why weve been making key decisions like the extra money for the National Health Service, the long-term plan for the National Health Service, and there is still a domestic agenda that I want to get on with."The PMs victory in the confidence vote means that she cannot face another such attempt to oust her until the end of this year.Mrs May said that, after withdrawal, the UK still needed to agree its future relations with Brussels.Speaking as she attended an EU-League of Arab States summit in Egypt, the PM added: "Theres a second part of the negotiations in terms of the future economic partnership, the future security partnership."We have set out a clear framework for that in the Political Declaration. Thats the basis on which those negotiations would go forward."The complete package of Brexit, we leave on March , but also we have to put in place that future relationship because thats about the sustainable long-term relationship of the UK with the EU."

title: umunna-sets-sights-on-tig-leadership-as-labour-and-tories-braced-for-more-defections
story: Today, TIG, as it has become known, prepares to hold its inaugural meeting and, as it does so, the leaderships of the Labour and Conservative parties are bracing themselves for more defections.Mr Umunna, who represents Streatham in London, is one of eight ex-Labour MPs who have joined forces with three former Tories to create the new centrist force in the Commons.Askedhe was going to be TIGrsquos leader, the -year-old politician told Sky News Sophy Ridge on Sunday: "Im clear I want to play the biggest role in this group and one of the things about the way we operate is the recognition that were all leaders."Mr Umunnas comments came as his former colleague Barry Gardiner, the Shadow International Trade Secretary, accused him of quitting Labour to join TIG because he knew he could never become leader of his former party."It was fairly clear to me the reason he wanted to leave the Labour Party was that he knew he could never lead the Labour Party," Mr Gardiner told the same programme. "This is about personality."Mr Ummuna has claimed the current party system is "broken" and has spoken in favour of proportional representation.He added: "Were quite clear that we believe that we should have the closest possible relationship with the European Union because were internationalists."We believe that the inidual should be given a  to succeed, that we have inidual responsibilities ourselves and people dont want their lives to be run by the state, that they would support education, infrastructure and the health service but also we believe, ultimately, that work is an incredibly important value and we need to give people a level of security that they expect."Now none of the established parties are providing the answers to those challenges."The former Shadow Business Secretary continued: "If within our group we are capable of forming a consensus around policies when we get to that point, then we have a much better chance of coming up with something that can unite our ided nation."Mr Umunna claimed Labour had become ldquounbearable and, commenting on anti-Semitism within the party, said: "I blame Jeremy Corbyn but I also blame other people who have acted as bystanders."It is disgraceful that the Shadow Cabinet has not done more, not been more vocal, not demanded more, not threatened to resign over what has been going on over anti-Semitism and the problem is, its too easy to choose an easy le because there is a rule by fear."Meanwhile, his TIG colleague Heidi Allen, a former Conservative MP, speaking about the roll-out of the Governments flagship new benefits system Universal Credit, told BBC Ones The Andrew Marr Show: "It could be the most phenomenal benefit system out there but, at the moment, its treating people not like human beings, just like a sausage machine."Askedthe group would become a political party, the Cambridgeshire MP replied: "Yes, thats the hope, absolutely."**Responding to an assertion over the weekend by Emily Thornberry that TIG should be crushed, TIG MP Luciana Berger said such comments led her to believe she had made the right decision to quit Labour.ldquoActually, thats the culture of a politics that Im leaving behind, declared the Liverpool MP, adding: ldquoWe should be operating in an open way, in a tolerant way, that that is what in the st century the country deserves."

title: the-school-where-record-numbers-of-pupils-study-home-economics
story: Sally Cameron, health and technology teacher at St Margaretrsquos, said home economics had been given a radical overhaul with a change of name, a new focus to lessons and the introduction of taster sessions in surrounding primary schools.She said: ldquoWe donrsquot call ourselves home economics. We changed because we felt it was an outdated term and did not reflect the work that is going on in schools.ldquoIn the first three years we teach topics such as the relationship between food and health and how food can prevent or cause dietary diseases.ldquoWe are educating the pupils on how to be clever consumers so they are aware of the labelling on food, packaging and advertising and we also look at other factors such as whether foods are free range or organic.Pupils also learn to cook, with popular lessons focusing on creating healthy versions of their favourite foods such as low-fat pizzas, fruit kebabs or chicken nuggets that are baked rather than fried.Getting families on board is also a key part of the strategy, with parents and grandparents invited to attend school to see for themselves how the subject has changed.Mrs Cameron said: ldquoWe want to enthuse parents when their children are still young so we invite families to learning evenings where we tell them the subject is no longer just about cooking and sewing.ldquoIt is an academic subject that can get pupils into university, college and the world of work as well as giving them valuable skills for le.

title: letters-snp-claims-on-local-authority-cash-dont-add-up
story: Am I alone in questioning her logic on this  If local authorities really are getting ldquomore money, as the SNP leadership insists, why are real councils in the real world having to cut such important services in the face of growing need for those services  It makes no sense, particularly as the Scottish Government got a small increase in its allocation for this year. Why are councils getting cuts when there is more money in the pot In my experience the only people who are taken in by this are SNP politicians, in particular SNP councillors, who will happily whistle the ldquomore money theme as a musical accompaniment, while casting their votes to cut vital services for their own constituents. As that other nationalist, Margaret Thatcher, once said, "its a funny old world".Alex Gallagher,Labour Councillor Ward , North Ayrshire Council, Phillips Avenue, Largs.NICOLA Sturgeon took great delight, at the latest First Ministers Questions, to use one of her favourite ripostes to the opposition. When challenged over her ldquolack of spending" in certain areas she replied that there was no money left, therefore any changes must be matched by a loss of finance where in the system. Now she is facing a potential teachers strikewhere she has to come up with more money to avert this outcome.This leaves Ms Sturgeon with her own dilemma. If the financial offer to the teachers is raised, perhaps she will also inform the public where the consequent cut in services will come. If she does not give the teachers more money, she will have created a very damaging strike at a very sensitive time in the school calendar. Its Sturgeons choice.Dr Gerald Edwards,Broom Road, Glasgow.CATRIONA Stewart has some fun at the expense of those getting agitated about our First Minister taking time out to tour North America, quickly followed by a trip to France . In normal circumstances she would be right to defend the right of Scotlandrsquos leader to travel abroad promoting Scotlandrsquos best interests, but of course the circumstances are anything but normal, and from the content of Nicola Sturgeonrsquos speeches it was very clear that on this occasion promoting Scotlandrsquos business interests abroad was far from being the main point of the trips.Instead, the First Minister focused on trying to paint the UK Government in the worst possible light, and her own, as ever, as a shining example of all that is good. No matter, it seems that, the SNP consistently misses its own targets in the critical public services that are supposed to be its priority, just as long as its leader can get onto the world stage and seek to undermine the UK and our place within it.Keith Howell,White Moss, West Linton, Peeblesshire.CHRISTOPHER H Jonescontends that the SNP is "driven by Holyrood well, the Holyrood Parliament is elected by voters in Scotland, and accountable to voters in Scotland, unlike the position at Westminster where Scotland has a mere  seats out of . I must correct Mr Jones in his assertion that "dissent within the ranks" of the SNP is not permitted, as lively and robust debates are a feature of SNP branch, constituency and group meetings, but dferences of opinion do not become the open warfare we see raging within the two main unionist parties. Bitter internal squabblings in the Conservative and Labour parties have now boiled over, at least a dozen MPs have left their parties, more are expected to leave, and others, including government ministers, are threatening to leave.Mr Jones argues that within the Unionist parties "whilst some members may be disenchanted with a party position at least they are free to go their own way" indeed, they have gone their own way right out of their parties and formed their own group. The reality is that both Labour and the Tories are in not so much as a deep hole as a bottomless pit, and no amount of digging will get them out of it.Ruth Marr, Grampian Road, Stirling.IT would be instructive for those supporting the status quo of government to think carefully of the rules by which certain "democratic decisions have been made or rather concocted, and which are a backdrop to the present growing appeal of Scottish independence.In  the conditions for the Scottish devolution referendum were imposed by Westminster. Briefly, the determining factor was thatless than  per cent of the eligible electorate voted Yes, the Act of  which determined the referendum, would be repealed. The Yes vote was . per cent but with a turn-out of  per cent the resultant Yes vote was . per cent of the eligible electorate and the Act was repealed. This electoral contrivance is unique, and contrasts spectacularly with that governing the EU referendum of  and even more spectacularly with the usual rules of UK General Elections.In , when account is taken of the turn-out in the General Election, the Conservative Party achieved less than  per cent support of the eligible electorate and less than  per cent of the actual vote, but under the Westminster rules it formed the minority government, albeit having bought the ldquocourtesy of the DUP.In  the Yes vote to leave the EU was . per cent but after factoring in the turn-out of  per cent the Yes vote becomes . per cent of those eligible.In  the Yes vote in the Scottish referendum was similarly . per cent.The conclusion that only an independent Scotland with its own written constitution will be able, in its own interest, to unscramble the rules by which the Westminster establishment protects its position is plain to see.J Hamilton,G , Jackson Place, Bearsden.Read more: Catriona Stewart on Nicola Sturgeons trips

title: from-paisley-to-indiana-scottish-sculptor-unveils-epic-new-work-for-the-university-of-notre-dame
story: The towering, ft sculpture of Leon Battista Alberti, one of the giants of Italyrsquos Renaissance, is currently in the studios of Alexander Stoddart in Paisley, waiting to be cast in bronze and cross the Atlantic to its ultimate destination.The sculpture of the Italian architect, writer, poet and author is to be part of one of the USrsquos leading universities, the Universityof Notre Dame in Indiana.There, the towering figure will be part of a rebuilt architecture department.The sculptor, whose studios are located within the Paisley campus of the University of the West of Scotland, has shared an image of the sculpture, being worked on by studio assistants Lindsay McQuarrie and Zoe Roy.With iders in one hand, and a scroll in the other, Alberti, Mr Stoddart said, is looking at the remains of classical Rome - deep in the past - as well as looking into the future.In a detail which alludes to the Scottish site of its creation, Albertirsquos left leg is beside a Roman altar, to Diana and Apollo, which is part of the Hunterian Museumrsquos collections at the University of Glasgow.The plaster statue will shortly be move to Black Isle Bronze, where it will be cast in bronze, before itrsquos y shipped journey across the Atlantic: it is due to be unveiled officially at the University of Notre Dame in the summer.Mr Stoddart, known for his neo-classical sculptures - including David Hume and Adam Smith on the Royal Mile in Edinburgh, said it is the result of around two years of work.ldquoHe has iders in his hand - he is measuring the world. He is staring at Rome, and that is what is there in that block by his leg - so he is looking  years back, but also to the future, back and forward at the same time.Mr Stoddart said he is also currently working on a figure, also for the US, that will be taller.The sculptor noted that the figure of Albert , simply clothed, is distant from the current ldquoimperium of modernism.The artist said that Notre Damersquos School of Architecture, established in , perhaps aptly, emphasises traditional architectural ideals and theories.The architect John Simpson has designed the universityrsquos new School of Architecture building, and has worked with Mr Stoddart before, notably the Queenrsquos Gallery at Buckingham Palace.Mr Stoddart, born in , studied at Glasgow School of Art and the University of Glasgow.

title: mark-smith-the-five-big-hurdles-the-new-bbc-channel-is-going-to-have-to-overcome
story: This problem with young people has been one of the biggest issues on the minds of BBC producers as they prepare for the new channel and rightly so. The fact the young ones donrsquot watch TV in the way their parents do poses an existential threat to broadcasters, particularly a broadcaster like the BBC that expects everyone to pay for channels eventhey donrsquot watch them. Ironically, the people who do still watch terrestrial TV every day ndash the over s ndash are the only ones who donrsquot have to pay the licence fee.The BBCrsquos response to this problem has been to come up with ideas for the new channel that are firmly aimed at under s. Last night, for example, there was a show presented by Iain Stirling of Love Island. There was also a programme that had a whf of Channel  reality-show about it: Getting Hitched Asian Style. The only old fogies on opening night were Jack and Victor, but even their show, Still Game, is a big hit with the under s.Read more: The Question Time row raises profound questions for the BBCThe big question is whether this strategy is going to work and I have my doubts. Recently, I spent a few days with my godchildren who are aged between nine and , and what was striking about how they spent their time was that they didnrsquot switch on the BBC. Not once. For someone like me, or anyone  in their s who grew up with Basil Brush and Blue Peter, thatrsquos pretty extraordinary: young people arenrsquot watching the BBC regularlyat all. The question is: will they change their habits as they get older or is it the BBC that will have to change For the moment, the makers of the new channel are proceeding on the basis that they can still attract young viewers. But whether they can or not is just the first of the hurdles the channel is going to have to overcome, the second being whether they can attract an audience in the way that matters. In the old days, TV was about overnight viewing figures ndash bums on seats ndash but the director of BBC Scotland, Donalda MacKinnon, has already been managing expectations by saying the new channel will not be about the size of the audience. Thatrsquos not-very-subtle code for: the traditional viewing figures for the new channel are going to be very low.The question is whether it matters and, in a way, it doesnrsquot because viewing figures are not as important as they once were - itrsquos just as important that a programme does well on iPlayer and social media. That means that, to prove its worth, the channel is going to have to do well online and produce programmes that are shared by a younger audience. The fact that one of the early programmes is about the make-up artist Jamie Genevieve is a clue to where wersquore going here ndash she has more than a million Instagram followers.Where it gets dficult is whether the BBC can rise to this challenge, which leads to the third hurdle: the balance problem. The BBC is proud of its policy on balance but, as I pointed out in my column on Question Time the other day, the BBCrsquos idea of balance has led it to the ludicrous position that, for every environmental scientist on TV, there has to be a climate-change denier. ldquoBalance can also lead to some very dull TV and thatrsquos not going to help the new channel get its news reports shared online. People increasingly like news with attitude whereas the BBC does sensible. Sensible doesnrsquot go viral.The fourth, and perhaps the biggest, hurdle for the new channel is also, in a way, the reason for its creation in the first place. For years, there was pressure from the SNP for a Scottish Six news programe and the new channel is the end result ndash in other words, itrsquos the BBCrsquos response to a political argument rather than audience demand. The problem for the BBC, though, is the Scottish nationalists who most loudly demanded change are also the least likely to watch the new coverage because of its perceived bias ndash most of the talk among this group is about the reasons they wonrsquot watch.Read more: Of course the BBC is biasedThe recent row over an alleged plant in the audience of Question Time has not helped in this regard. There has also been very little evidence that the BBC is willing to seriously consider whether theyrsquore getting it right on alleged bias. In fact, Hayley Valentine, the editor of the new Scottish Nine news programme, made the extraordinary statement that she did not know ldquoa single journalist who brought any bias to work with them which is anti-logic of the worst kind: BBC journalists have bias just like any other human does, which is why the BBC has rules to try to overcome it.The allegation of bias also has serious consequences for the Scottish version of Question Time which is doomed to death by a thousand nationalist cuts before it even starts. The programme also faces the fth and final hurdle, which is money. BBC Scotland has already admitted they cannot afford to take their Scottish Question Time around the country which will not only make the channel feel Glasgow-centric , it will highlight the fact that the new channel simply doesnrsquot have the money it needs.Can the new channel get over these hurdles  Possibly, but remember previous experiments by the BBC. BBC Choice, which included regional iations for Scotland ndash axed in . The Scottish version of Newsnight ndash axed in . Scotland , which had average viewing figures as low as , ndash axed after less than three years. Perhaps the new BBC channel will be dferent to all of those, but it has something of the same feel doesnrsquot it  An attempt to be dferent without any great ability to be interesting. An attempt to be Scottish when very few people are watching.

title: oscars-olivia-colman-wins-best-actress-for-the-favourite
story: The star of The Favourite triumphed over The Wersquos Close, as well as Lady Gaga, Melissa McCarthy and Yalitza Aparicio for an unexpected win at the ceremony, where Green Book was named best picture.Colman was visibly shocked as her name was called and was helped to her feet by her husband Ed Sinclair and co-star Emma Stone, who planted a kiss on her cheek.Taking to the stage, she said: ldquoItrsquos genuinely quite stressful. This is hilarious. I got an Oscar!ldquoOK, I have to thank lots of people. If, by the way, I forget anybody Irsquom going to find you later and Irsquom going to give you all a massive snog and Irsquom really sorryImight forget now."Any little girl thats practicing her speech on the telly, you never know."Congratulations to @TheAcademy winner for Best Actress Olivia Colman. #Oscars #TheFavourite pic hNphloHmdash The FavouriteFebruary , Payingtribute to her director Yorgos Lanthimos as well as Stone and fellow co-star Rachel Weisz, she added: ldquoYorgos, my best director and the best film, and with Emma and Rachel, the two loveliest women in the world to fall in love with, and to go to work with every day, I mean, you can imagine, it wasnrsquot a hardship.ldquoAnd to be in this category with these extraordinary women, and Glenn Closehellip yoursquove been my idol for so long and this is not how I wanted it to be and I think yoursquore amazing and I love you very much.She added that she hoped her children were watching and said: ldquoIf yoursquore not, then, well done, but I sort of hope you are. This is not going to happen again.ldquoAnd any little girl who is practising their speech on the telly, you never know. I used to work as a cleaner and I loved that job, I did spend quite a lot of my time imagining this.Green Book won the biggest prize of the night as the surprise winner of best picture, a category largely expected to go to Roma.The film about a black jazz musician and a white driver travelling through the segregated US deep south also won the best supporting actor Oscar for Mahershala Ali, as well as best original screenplay.Rami Malek was named best actor for his role as Freddie Mercury in the Queen biopic Bohemian Rhapsody and planted a passionate kiss on the lips of his girlfriend and co-star Lucy Boynton before making his way to the stage.Regina King took the best supporting actress prize for her role in If Beale Street Could talk, leading to the most erse group of acting winners in the history of the Oscars.Shallow from A Star Is Born was named best original song and Lady Gaga addressed her director and co-star Bradley Cooper as she collected the gong, saying: ldquoBradley, there is not a single person who could have sang this song with me but you. Thank you for believing in me.ldquoIf you are at home sitting on your couch and watching this now, all I can say is this is hard work. Men And A Lady #################################### pic oSCXtPTfmdash Mark RonsonFebruary , ldquoIrsquove worked hard for a long time. This is not about winning, what itrsquos about is not giving up. If you have a dream fight for it.ldquoItrsquos not about how many times you are rejected and how many times you fall down, itrsquos how many times you stand up and keep going.Cooper and Gaga also performed the song at the ceremony, with the pair looking intently into each otherrsquos eyes during the duet before Cooper sat next to her at the piano.History was made earlier in the night when Ruth Carter became the first black winner to collect the best costume design prize, while Hannah Beachler became the first black winner of the production design gong, both for their work on Black Panther.The Marvel superhero movie was also recognised for its original score."As artists, our job is to look where others dont.This responsibility becomes much more important in times when we are being encouraged to look away.Muchas gracias a Libo. Muchas gracias a mi familia.Muchas gracias a Meacutexico."-Alfonso Cuaroacuten#Oscarsmdash Netflix FilmFebruary , The black-and-white, Spanish-language film Roma won three prizes, collecting the best director prize for Alfonso Cuaron, best cinematography, also for Cuaron, and best foreign language film.Bohemian Rhapsody was the most awarded film at the ceremony, with prizes for Malek, film editing, sound mixing and sound editing.

title: crossing borders with your dog after brexit
story: A. The answer to this all depends on whether we leave the EU with or without a deal and when you want to travel.Pet passports wont be valid with a no deal BrexitAt the minute, you are supposed to have a pet passport for your dogtheyrsquore travelling from the UK to the EU and vice versa, although it is my understanding that there are no checks on pets crossing the Republic or Ireland and Northern Ireland border at the minute. Pet passports list the dferent treatments your pet has had and ensures they are microchipped and up to date with their rabies vaccine.Read more: JD Wetherspoon favours more UK products as Brexit moves closerThe passport means your pooch wont have to go into quarantine on arrival.If the UK leaves without a deal, then the rules will change and pet passports issued in the UK would no longer be valid.In this case, pet owners would need to get a health certicate - and the bad news is, this will take at least four months. title: embroidery exhibition at heritage centre
story: The Garioch Heritage Centre in Inverurie will host the Embroiderer#s Guild Lest We Forget embroidery exhibition next week.The free exhibition will run at the centre from Tuesday, February  to Tuesday, March .In  the Guild in conjunction with SSAFAinvited its members to take part in the commemoration of the ending of WW a  years previously by producing one heart.The plan being that each heart would be included in at least one exhibition, ideally, as near to their home location.Thus making unique and thoughtful exhibitions to fulfil the hope of a generation not to be forgotten.Using cloth, thread and textile each heart interprets a unique story of comradeship, bravery, victory or setback told by those ing from the Great War or in their heartfelt letters to those back home.The hearts illustrate to a new generation the men and the animals that accompanied them the unorms worn and medals won the regiments that fought together and the family members fondly remembered the songs that kept their spirits high and the words they wrote to those back home. This is a one-off, not to be missed, opportunity to view the  Scottish Hearts in the North East of Scotland. title: inverurie youth sports foundation appoints hannah as ambassador
story: Inverurie Youth Sports Foundationis delighted to announce the appointment of Hannah Miley OLY as the IYSF ambassador.Hannah will be working alongside the IYSF trustees as they continue to provide financial assistance and support to young people as they strive to achieve their sporting ambitions.The IYSF was established in  to support and promote the future development of youth in sport within the Garioch area. Since its establishment the IYSF has provided assistance to over  athletes, including three para athletes and nine sports clubs organisations across  dferent sports.To date a number of the young sports people supported by the IYSF have gone onto compete at national and international level including the Olympics, Winter Olympics and Commonwealth Games.The IYSF is committed to providing financial support to inidual young persons in sport to ensure that they are able to continue participating in their chosen sport, and to let them take their sporting performance to the next stage and attend national championships and competitions.In addition, the IYSF extends its support to local sports clubs, by providing financial support to a body looking to set up a new club in the local area and providing financial funding to existing clubs which has been used to help towards coaching costs.Willie Lippe, IYSF trustee, said of the recent appointment: “Having Hannah Miley OLY as the IYSF ambassador will be a huge benefit to the IYSF.“Not only will Hannah be a voice of the Inverurie Youth Sports Foundation but as an outstanding sportsperson in her own right, she will be inspirational to young people active in sport today.”In her IYSF ambassador role Hannah presented to Garioch Rugby Club last  Sunday, February , inspiring the next generation of sports people.The IYSF is a charitable foundation that was founded by local entrepreneur Steven Ferguson and his family.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: last call for run garioch entries

title: london fashion week for stylist kelsey
story: A north east hairdresser visited London last week to take part in one of fashion#s most prestigious shows.Senior stylist at Rebecca Carr Hair Salon in Kintore, Ky Catto, was selected as one of the session team for London Fashion Week , which ran from Friday  to Tuesday  February.It is the third time that she has worked at the show, having been selected following a robust audition process at Toni  Guy’s training academy in London in .Ky, from Aberdeen, has been working in the industry since she was a Saturday girl aged  before leaving school at  to take on a hairdressing apprenticeship.She has worked with Rebecca Carr since the salon launched three years ago.Speaking ahead of the event, Ky said: “I have been allocated two designers, DB Berdan and Kalissa, so I have spent time getting a good feel for their inidual styles and getting a better understanding of what they want and need. “Creating styling with designers at LFW is a great experience and working alongside stylists from across the world gives me the opportunity to learn new skills and techniques that improves my offering to my clients.”Ky has travelled to LFW twice with salon owner, Rebecca Carr, and worked with other upcoming designers.Last year, Rebecca worked with fashion designer, Paul Costelloe at the show.She said: “LFW is a brilliant opportunity for any stylist but you are only chosenyou are at the very top of your game so I’m really proud that Ky has been invited back for a third session at the show. “She worked very hard at the audition stage initially and her work over the past two shows has led to more opportunities.“It can be quite a daunting experience for young stylists but it also a fantastic career opportunity.”Rebecca added: “I have always been focussed on ensuring the Rebecca Carr team has the chance to experience events like this and attend the best industry training to hone their skills.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Delay to Wick 20 mph speed limit plans
story: THE brakes have been put on plans to introduce a  mph speed limit on the majority of roads in Wick.The proposal was mooted by Highland Council as a way to improve road safety and encourage walking and cycling.However, Wick members of the Caithness committee this week described the scheme as "a blunt instrument" and said other measures to reduce speed would be more effective. They also felt the consultation period should be extended by three weeks to allow the public more time to respond to the plan.Speaking at the meeting in Wick Town Hall on Wednesday, Councillor Nicola Sinclair said she was "very much in favour" of improving road safety but was concerned about the scale of the  mph limit and claimed there should be a longer period of consultation."The consultation took place over the Christmas period and I dont think people got enough opportunity to get their views heard," she said.Full report in Fridayrsquos John OrsquoGroat Journal.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. He was unable to confirmMeghan would attend along with her husband, but said it would be ldquotruly fantastic for Caithness and help put it on the mapthe royal couple turned up.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will welcome their first child this spring.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Wick Francis Street Club placed in liquidation
story: WICKS Francis Street Club has been placed in liquidation, it was confirmed on Thursday.According to provisional liquidator Iain Fraser, a partner with FRP Advisory, the decision was made following a decline in membership, rising costs and unsustainable cash-flow problems. The club ndash founded in the s as a British Legion ndash has now closed and six staff have been made redundant.Mr Fraser said: "The Francis Street Club has been a landmark social, entertainment and sports venue in Caithness for nearly  years. Sadly, the club has been suffering severe financial problems and liquidation was the only option available to the committee."We are working closely with the relevant agencies, including the Redundancy Payments Office, to ensure the staff receive as much support as possible. We are now offering the assets of the business for sale, including the building, fixtures and fittings, and would urge interested parties to contact our Aberdeen office as soon as possible on   ."The Francis Street Club started was a long-established social, entertainment and sporting venue which attracted some well-known names through its doors, including former world snooker champion Stephen Hendry who staged an exhibition match there.It served as a social club and ran both football and darts teams, both well supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.The premises closed last month. At the time, a statement issued by the club said: "It was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , ."A note subsequently posted on the door read: "We have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course."Monday  Feb  : AM

title: accessibility top of the agenda for northlink
story: Changes are being made by NorthLink Ferries to make their services more accessible to all.On board information workshops and the introduction of new website software are the latest efforts being made by the company to improve services for those with additional support needs.The ferry operator implemented its new Recite Me accessibility tool on its website, this month, to make it more suitable to folk#s needs. The new software — which can be used on desktops and mobile browsers — allows website visitors to customise what they see and hear, from changing the contrast settings, language, font size and more.In the UK, there are estimated to be . million people with a learning disability and . million people who have English as a second language. ‘Recite Me’ has the ability to translate the NorthLink Ferries website into more than  languages — including Scots Gaelic . It can also translate text-to-speech to help visually impaired users and focus screen areas for those with dyslexia.On Monday, February , teams on board MV Hamnavoe hosted an Access Panel Orkney session, where staff were provided with disability awareness training. During the two-hour session, staff were able to experience what it’s like to have a disability by wearing glasses that simulated blindness, used wheelchairs and crutches and had their hearing dampened.Carolyn Grfiths of Access Panel Orkney said: “The aim of our session was to let staff experience disabilities first-hand so they can empathise with passengers’ needs.#All of us running the training have a disability so we were able to provide first-hand examples of what accessible travel is like for us. We were delighted to be welcomed on board to provide this training and it’s great to see a company like Serco NorthLink Ferries take accessibility for passengers seriously.”The MV Hjaltland will also host a Making Connections workshop today, Friday, February . The workshop will look at how passengers navigate potential barriers when changing from one mode of transport to another. Making Connections brings disabled people together with transport operators to discuss, address and plan how travel connections can be made easier.Seumas Campbell, customer service director at NorthLink Ferries, said: “Catering for passengers with ying degrees of disability is an important part of our service provision. Whether they are using our website to book their journey, making a connection from other forms of public transport or coming on board one of our vessels, we believe that passengers should experience a service that caters to all their needs.“The new website software will allow visitors to customise what they see and hear and as more and more visitors from around the world choose NorthLink Ferries to travel to the Northern Isles, ‘Recite Me’ is a great tool to help them plan and book their journey.“Our workshops are also a great way in training our staff on how they can best help and understand passengers’ needs. We pride ourselves on having a great team that always provides the best service so it’s important that we’re constantly refreshing their training.”For more information on accessibility for passengers on NorthLink Ferries, you can visit www.northlinkferries copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: council issues kirkyards apology
story: Orkney Islands Council has made an official apology following public concern about the way the county#s kirkyards are being managed.Distraught families and dismayed public officials have spoken out in recent weeks, after a scheme to improve the safety of cemeteries triggered reports that headstones were being laid flat without relatives being notied.Last week, a council insider told The Orcadian that — in failing to contact families — the council was disregarding government guidelines on cemetery maintenance.“It says it’s good practice to inform the families and give them an opportunity to repair the memorial, and that’s just not being done at all,” the inside source said.The Orcadian also heard from Stewart Spence, whose father#s headstone had been laid down in the Sandwick kirkyard with no notication from the council. This was despite the fact that the name and address of the person they needed to contact — his mother Edna — was engraved on the memorial.#Vandals couldn#t have done a better job,# he said.Following this wave of public concern, OIC convener Harvey Johnston and chief executive Alistair Buchan have now released a statement apologising for the concern and upset that this project has caused.#Following a tragic accident involving a young child at a Glasgow cemetery, the Scottish Government asked councils to carry out detailed inspections in the interests of public safety,# they said.#We therefore engaged in the kirkyard safety programme for all the right reasons, but recognise that the process we have followed needs to be improved. It was never envisaged that the resulting work would leave kirkyards in the condition they are in. We are sorry about the concern and upset this has led to.#As a caring organisation, responsive to public concern, we will restore kirkyards to the condition people would expect. We will also consider how best to contact and discuss the remedial work required with those concerned. People’s safety is an important concern for us and we will continue to carry out headstone inspections. As at Warebeth , we will use blue pegs to mark stones identied as being unsafe and highlight these to local community representatives.#These stones will not be touched until we publicise the inspection results and give relatives the time they need to discuss with us any work they might wish to carry out themselves.#The statement also confirmed that further updates from the council will be provided further updates over the weeks ahead.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: german fleet salvage sites archaeology project results published online
story: With the centenary of the scuttling of the German High Seas Fleet in Scapa Flow fast approaching in June of this year, a fascinating insight into remains of aspects of the wrecks has now been published online.Historic Environment Scotland commissioned the Orkney Research Centre for Archaeology and SULA Diving to complete a full survey of the wrecks and debris remaining on the sea bed following the inter-war salvage operations.The seven remaining ships of the High Seas Fleet have seen Scapa Flow become one of the most well-known e sites in the World. Those wrecks are still the primary focus of recreational ers, but the remains of the vessels that were mostly recovered and removed from Scapa Flow have also been a recognised ing resource for many years.However, the exact extent and composition of these so-called salvage sites was unknown until this week, when the report of the second phase of work on these sites was published online.The overall aim of the Scapa Flow Salvage Sites Project was to determine what remains of the many vessels of the German High Seas Fleet that were salvaged in the years that followed their scuttling in June .Phase One, undertaken over the winter of  , involved a side scan sonar survey of the main anchorages and other areas thought to have been involved in the salvage process.In the second phase of this project, ers and remotely operated vehicles examined and recorded the remains in detail.The overall result is that the vast majority of salvage sites in Scapa Flow have been located and the remains at each site have been directly investigated and recorded.The full report is now available for public download through the Scapa Flow Historic Wreck website http:www.scapaflowwrecks projects salvage-sites-phase- Further details in The Orcadian on Thursday.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: in the footsteps of dr john rae
story: Next month will see a group of intrepid adventurers undertake a -mile mission in the Canadian Arctic, retracing the footsteps of one of Orkney#s most renowned, yet also overlooked, sons — Dr John Rae.The Arctic Return expedition will see a four-man team set off from Naujaat — also known as Repulse Bay — in late March, aiming to retrace the footsteps made by the surgeon, explorer and surveyor in .It was on that expedition that the explorer finally discovered an open channel to the east of King William Island in the high arctic. Known today as Rae Strait, it was the missing link in what would become the first navigable Northwest Passage.He also reported back on the ill-fated Franklin expedition, reported evidence of cannibalism — findings which were effectively rejected by the then establishment, and which led to Rae#s achievements being almost completely ignored.The modern-day team, who hope to raise further awareness of these achievements, will be led by Scottish-born and Canada-based expedition leader David Reid, with Scotland also represented by Broxburn-based former Royal Marine Richard Smith.The team will also include two Canadians — adventure film-maker Gerry Tutte and adventurer Frank Wolf.Over  years later and supported with modern-day kit from outdoor specialists Tiso, the explorers are hard at work preparing for the physical and mental challenge of hauling kg sledges for nine hours daily and for up to  consecutive days.Their route will cover undulating, windswept tundra, river valleys and sea ice during what can be the coldest time of year.The Arctic expedition will finish once the four explorers have finally reached Gjoa Haven on King William Island.Mr Smith said: #The Arctic Return expedition will be extremely tough but ultimately our aim is to raise awareness fo the exploits of John Rae and to help restore his rightful place as one of the greatest Scottish explorers in history. It is also our hope that this awareness will inspire the public to support fundraising efforts by the John Rae Society, to restore Rae#s birthplace at the Hall of Clestrain in Oprhir.The team have said any addition funds raised are to be used to produce a documentary film and book about the le and exploits of Rae, the expedition and the history communities, culture and wildle of the Arctic.The public will be able to track the team#s progress at their official website and through social media.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: mcarthur welcomes fuel poverty re think
story: Orkney’s MSP, Liam McArthur has welcomed Scottish Government plans to ensure that its Fuel Poverty Bill recognises the higher costs faced by those living in remote rural and island areas.During the stage one debate in Parliament yesterday, Wednesday, the Housing Minister, Kevin Stewart indicated that he would bring forward amendments to the bill to include an ‘uplt’ to the minimum income standard for rural and island communities. Mr McArthur believes this reflects a change in approach by the government, after months of campaigning by the Orkney MSP and a range of organisations involved in tackling fuel poverty across the Highlands and Islands.During his remarks, Mr McArthur pointed out that when it comes to fuel poverty, rural and island areas are disproportionately affected, with Orkney having the highest proportion of households in fuel poverty and extreme fuel poverty anywhere in Scotland.Commenting after the debate, Mr McArthur said: “Fuel poverty blights communities across Scotland, but there is no doubt that it has a disproportionate impact on rural and island areas. Until recently, however, the Scottish Government appeared unwilling to recognise this fact or indeed the higher costs faced by those living in our rural and island communities.“Over recent months, working with a range of organisations with a wealth of experience and expertise in tackling fuel poverty, I have made the case for the Minister, Kevin Stewart to think again.  It was a case that the Local Government Committee was also persuaded to support.“I am delighted, therefore, that the Minister has had a change of heart and committed to bring forward amendments to his bill at stage two that better reflect the specic nature of fuel poverty in places like Orkney.  I look forward to seeing the detail of those amendments and will work with Mr Stewart, and local stakeholders in Orkney, to make sure we get this right.“Given the impact fuel poverty can have, not just on people’s quality of le but their physical and mental health, this bill has the potential to make a real dference.  For that to happen, it must be both effective and ambitious in eradicating fuel poverty from communities across the country.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney art student to represent scotland
story: An Orkney College student will be one of  folk to represent Scotland at a special exhibition in Venice, Italy, this year.Jenny Sprenger has been selected to attend a professional development programme as part of the Scotland + Venice  exhibition during this year’s Biennale of Art in the city.Exhibition assistant Jenny will be given the opportunity to support Scotland’s presentation of new video work by Charlotte Prodger during the Biennale Arte  which runs from May to November.On being selected Jenny Sprenger said: “I am both thrilled and honoured to have been selected to be part of this opportunity, and I am looking forward to the chance to connect with other artists and see world-class contemporary art in the flesh.”Cove Park — an international artists residency centre based in Scotland — is spearheading the Scotland + Venice Professional Development Programme. This year, in addition to partnering with six Scottish art schools and colleges, the programme will benefit from new collaborations with the Scottish Contemporary Art Networkand Templar Arts and Leisure Centre , Argyll and Bute. title: Ambitious plan sets goals to end fuel poverty
story: PEOPLE across Ross-shire could benefit after the Scottish Government incorporated changes into its own draft legislation to ldquoend the scourge of fuel poverty.An earlier barrage of criticism claimed the Fuel Poverty Bill missed the target when it came to delivering for the ldquoworst affected areas.Fuel poverty is defined as when households spend  per cent or more of income on domestic fuel ndash reckoned to account for one in four homes in Scotland.The figure is understood to be signicantly higher across swathes of Ross-shire, hitting homes which are not on the gas grid and reliant on oil and low-income households.Minister for local government, housing and planning, Kevin Stewart, promised to include ldquoa rural, remote and island minimum income standard in poverty calculations as well as what he called ldquoa rural uplt.He was speaking at the first stage of a Holyrood debate of the Bill which aims to cut fuel-poor households to five per cent by  from the current national average of almost  per cent.The move was welcomed by rural housing associations and local councillors but Highlands Tory MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston vowed to maintain pressure on the government to deliver on what was promised.He said: "The minister announced that a new rural, remote and island minimum income standard will be included in their fuel poverty calculations alongside a rural uplt. We will be looking to strengthen the Bill as it progresses through the Scottish Parliament and ensuring that the Scottish Governmentrsquos pledges are met."Before Wednesdayrsquos debate Mr Stewart said: ldquoWithin this ground-breaking legislation, not only are we one of the few countries in the world to define fuel poverty, we are also setting a goal towards eradicating it.ldquoBy changing the definition of fuel poverty so itrsquos more closely aligned to relative income poverty and taking steps to ensure it works for remote rural and island communities, we are ensuring our support is focussed on those who need it most."He added: "In this day and age, it is unacceptable that any Scottish household should have to choose between having the heating on and cooking their dinner.Councillor Ian Cockburn, who represents the Wester Ross, Strathpeffer and Lochalsh welcomed the Bill as "something has to be done about fuel poverty" while arguing it is also time to rethink infrastructure like the national grid."It is ambitious but has to be tried to get fuel poverty down in rural areas. We are one of the most energy rich countries in the world so we should be able to get something done. Too many people take it as just being part of the landscape up here so we need to change that thinking as well to get people the assistance that they need."Scotland should not be in this state. But you have to look back, the National Grid was set up at the end of the war, the Highlands is considered off-grid despite supplying much of the rest of the country through hydro and wind power. It is time for a rethink."Calum Macaulay, chief executive of Invergordon-based Albyn Housing Society, said: ldquoWe welcome this development in the Scottish Governmentrsquos approach to addressing fuel poverty in rural areas. The push to include minimum income standards feels like a signicant step forwards. This is something that the Rural and Islands Housing Association Forum has been promoting for quite some time."This has included research undertaken with the support of Highlands and Islands Enterprise and others into minimum income standards in rural communities. The results of this highlighted the pressures of lower average household incomes and higher average fuel costs across the northern parts of Scotland."What do you think  Share your views by emailing newsdesk@spp-groupMonday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Black Isle authors French connection helps ensure nothing is lost in translation
story: Vee Walkers Major Toms War, partly set in France during WWI, is now fittingly being translated into French for a new edition of the book.Such has been the response to the novel that the Black Isle author has already been on a book tour and visited France on the back of it. The annual Franco-Scottish Society Alexander Gray Fund Lecture in Inverness on Friday promises to be alight-hearted bilingual talk from Ms Walker and her "long-suffering" Parisian translator Richard Kausch.Major Tomrsquos War is a moving novel set in France during the First World War, in part in the grim lsquozones occupeacuteesrsquo of northern France.Its characters are real people ndash and both author and translator have had to enter the minds of the novelrsquos key protagonists.The novel is published in English by Kashi House in London and the French edition should follow late this year or early in .Veeand Richard will be touring four of the regional Franco-Scottish Societies of Scotland this month.The groups exist to foster French language and culture in Scotland and meet monthly for French conversation or a lecture.Those who come along are welcome to join or to attend as a non-member. They are suitable for Higher Advanced Higher French pupils and their teachers.Vee confesses that as a French-speaking author she has not madeher translatorsle any easier: "Most translators produce a translation and the author would not have a clue about whether or not it is representative or accurate."My first degree was in French and although I am not a native speaker, I have had an opinion on nuance and vocabulary right the way through."Richard is currently revising the French text a second time to address the changes requested by my English publishers for the First Edition. He has the patience of a saint and I donrsquot know what I would have done without him!"Wersquore both looking forward to meeting audiences in Aberdeen, Edinburgh, Glasgow and Inverness on our tour around Scotland very much."Vee and Richardrsquos final tour slot is in Inverness on Friday, February  at the Glen Mhor Hotel,  Ness Bank, Invernessat .pm.Thelecture is free and will be followed by a French meal atpm. Theres a fixed menu.Reservations can be booked on   for lecture and or meal. Themeal is pound to members andpound to non-members.Monday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies.
